title: Victor Bonavia
text:
Victor Joseph Bonavia (2 September 1893 – 20 November 1948) was a <a href="Maltese%20people">Maltese</a> first-class <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er, physician and <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer.
Bonavia was born in <a href="Crown%20Colony%20of%20Malta">British Malta</a> in September 1893. He obtained his <a href="Doctor%20of%20Medicine">medical doctorate</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Malta">University of Malta</a>, before obtaining his <a href="Membership%20of%20the%20Royal%20Colleges%20of%20Physicians%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Membership of the Royal Colleges of Physicians</a> in London. Bonavia served in the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> and was commissioned as a temporary <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Army%20Medical%20Corps">Royal Army Medical Corps</a> in February 1917, being assigned to <a href="Thessaloniki">Thessaloniki</a>. He was promoted to lieutenant in full in February 1917, obtaining the temporary rank of <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> at the same time, a rank he gained in full in August 1920. He served in Thessaloniki until 1921, before transferring to <a href="Netley%20Hospital">Netley Hospital</a> in 1923, where he worked as a specialist registrar until 1924. From there he went to <a href="British%20India">British India</a>, where he played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for the <a href="Europeans%20cricket%20team">Europeans cricket team</a> on two occasions against the <a href="Sikhs%20cricket%20team">Sikhs</a> in 1926 and the <a href="Muslims%20cricket%20team">Muslims</a> in 1929. He also made a first-class appearance for the <a href="Punjab%20Governor%27s%20XI%20cricket%20team">Punjab Governor's XI</a> against <a href="Northern%20India%20cricket%20team">Northern India</a>. In his three first-class matches, Bonavia scored 104 runs with a highest score of 44. He was promoted to <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> in February 1929, with Bonavia remaining in India until 1930. After returning to England where he practiced at the <a href="Royal%20Herbert%20Hospital">Royal Herbert Hospital</a> in <a href="Woolwich">Woolwich</a>, he left for <a href="Republic%20of%20China%20%281912%E2%80%931949%29">China</a> in 1932, remaining there until 1936. He later served in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, during which he was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a> in October 1943, with his promotion to <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">colonel</a> following after the end of the war in November 1947. He was appointed to the BMH <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> in the <a href="Allied-occupied_Germany%23British_Zone">British occupation-zone in Germany</a> in 1947, where he died suddenly in November 1948.
